answers.answer: Hello Camronsdaddy!  Thank you for reaching out to us here at Medhelp.  We are not medical professionals, so any information that you receive here should be verified with your healthcare team.  I can only encourage you to take what others have posted below to heart and know that we are truly concerned for your well-being.  You have received much good advice and I hope that it helps you in dealing with what life has recently dealt you.There are only a couple of things that I want to put out there for you.  The first one deals with stress.  Stress hormones that your body releases compete with the insulin that you have administered, making it's effectiveness unpredictable.  Finding some way to cope with the everyday stress you are experiencing is very important to gaining better control over your blood glucose (bg) levels.  Meditation and physical exercise may help you to achieve a better stress level.  If you're not physically able to ride those horses, maybe just grooming or walking them would be emotionally beneficial to you and relaxing also.Keep up with your endocrinologist and therapy.  It's very important that you work with medical professionals that can provide you with the tools that you need to change and improve your life.  One thing to look forward to in this life is that things always change.Good luck to you & keep us posted on the changes in your life!

Hello, i have type 1 diabetes and am bipolar which used to be called manic-depression. i have been taking medications for both and i am glad you are trying to handle a difficult time. But you have answered your own question in ways in that i highly recommend you see a psychiatrist as they are medical doctors with special training in medications for mood disorders. i know how you feel as i've been more than a handful for my wife to deal with at times. But i have worked with my psychiatrist to try different medications to get to some that work because when i go through a depressive episode the care for my diabetes falters. i have many complications because i've been diabetic over thirty years now and the best thing i can do is keep my sugars as close to normal as i can which i have expressed to my psychiatrist so we can work harder to get meds that work.Good luck and try to keep a good attitude. buddhabret

Dear camronsdaddy,I am so sorry you are going through this. I am a volunteer and not a doctor so please understand that I am not qualified to give you medical advice. I can give you my own life experience dealing with type 1 diabetes regarding my son and autoimmune disorders that I also deal with myself.My son has had diabetes for 20 years and we do know that episodes of hypoglycemia and hyperglycemia alone will cause mood swings. I do agree with buddhabret, that you probably need to speak to a psychiatrist and to your endo. I am coming at this from many different points and this is about some of your medications.First, the research that I have done on depression and not only type 1 diabetes, but any chronic illness is more normal than not. The studies are varied, but can be very telling.You said you have type 1 diabetes and two other autoimmune disease's. One is addison's, can you share the third? I would like to recommend a website that may help with your addison's and possible medications you are taking for it. It is www.niddk.nih.gov/health/endo/pubs/addison/addison.htm.I have rheumatoid arthritis myself and know that prednisone can cause mood swings, especially when I am trying to reduce the amount that I am taking.You also seem to be experiencing hypoglycemic unawareness and this diffently needs to be discussed with your endo. It may take a consultation with different doctors who specialize in both type one and addison's.Please let us know how you are doing and watch for other comments from others here in the forum.I wish you the very best,dm

Hello Camronsdaddy,You sure have a lot of challenges in your path right now.  As you know, none of us here is a physician, and yet I'll add my encouragement to what you've rec'd from buddhabret & dm.A lot of what you described seems to be a cycle, where one difficult event (hypo, depressive cycle, uncontrolled BG) begins to trigger the other issues.  In similar situations, some folks feel anger, frustration and self-loathing.  They lash out at the external world -- unwittingly or otherwise.  Somehow, it may temporarily give us the illusion of control over SOMETHING when all else seems so out of control.  The benefit of trying to break the cycle by reaching again to your psychiatrist (or different one if you're needing to work with someone who's easier for you to approach), is that just about everything we do or think begins in our brain.  When the chemistry is off, we are likely impaired somewhat in our judgments and may neglect basic self care.You have so much going on, and I'll offer one small tip for regaining awareness of your hypos.  Do whatever it takes to avoid having a hypo for at least a week.  It takes a while for our recover from a hypo and, sadly, lack of recovery contributes a large measure to our inability to feel the NEXT one, if it comes too soon.  That's why we get some clusters of hypos.  For most of us, if we are diligent to avoid a hypo for a week or so, we can feel the next one that will - eventually - come along.It's hard work that faces you.  I can hear your commitment & passion for your child and your cat and the family members that are helping you.  Parenting is a huge responsibility (and joy!), and focusing on that may help you nurture yourself better. Do all that you can to be there for your child and to gain strength, one bit at a time.  By your actions, moods, behaviors, and words, you are teaching your child every day what it means to be an adult and how adults cope and manage difficult times.Let us know how the next steps go, okay?

In addition to the wonderful information that you have already been given, let me add two things:1. Being either hypoglycemic or hyperglycemic over an extended length of time can affect seratonin levels, which affect your moods. The next time you have bloodwork done, you may want to have the seratonin levels checked to see if your levels are normal. This can be treated if the numbers are off.2. Many medications can have the side effect of making you more sensitive to insulin. Some also can have side effects of raising or lowering glucose levels without changing insulin sensitivity. All of these will have adverse affects in diabetics. Doing frequent glucose checks after starting any new medication is necessary in order to be able to note any changes in glucose or sensitivity to insulin. If you notice changes from your "normal", then it may be smart to talk wtih the prescribing doctor to see if other medications can be used without the adverse side effects. ALL of your physicians should be aware of ALL of your medications, for the combinations can have all sorts of effects on your physical well-being as well as your emotions. So don't keep either your endo or any other physicians you may be seeing in the dark about medications that seem to have nothing to do with the health issue they are treating -- they may work poorly with other medications.
